articles.headline: Russian Court Sentences Griner to 9 Years, Raising Pressure on Biden
articles.snippet: Amid the hostility over the war in Ukraine, a court imposed nearly the maximum possible sentence on the American basketball star Brittney Griner, intensifying calls to win her release.
articles.abstract: Amid the hostility over the war in Ukraine, a court imposed nearly the maximum possible sentence on the American basketball star Brittney Griner, intensifying calls to win her release.
articles.lead_paragraph: A Russian court on Thursday sentenced the American basketball star Brittney Griner to nine years in a penal colony after convicting her on a drug charge, a harsh penalty that keeps her fate entwined with the geopolitical showdown over the war in Ukraine and ramps up already intense pressure on President Biden to win her release.
articles.byline: By Ivan Nechepurenko and Richard Pérez-Peña

articles.headline: Jurors Award Sandy Hook Parents $4 Million in Damages
articles.snippet: The decision was in the first of three trials to determine how much the Infowars conspiracy theorist must pay relatives of victims for spreading lies about the 2012 school shooting.
articles.abstract: The decision was in the first of three trials to determine how much the Infowars conspiracy theorist must pay relatives of victims for spreading lies about the 2012 school shooting.
articles.lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Texas — A Texas jury on Thursday awarded the parents of a child killed in the 2012 mass shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School more than $4 million in compensatory damages from the conspiracy theorist Alex Jones, the first time he has been held financially liable for defaming the victims’ parents by spreading lies that they were complicit in a government plot to stage the shooting as a pretext for gun control.

articles.headline: Musk Says Twitter Committed Fraud in Dispute Over Fake Accounts
articles.snippet: Twitter called the claims false and irrelevant in a high-profile legal fight over whether the billionaire can back out of a $44 billion deal to acquire the company.
articles.abstract: Twitter called the claims false and irrelevant in a high-profile legal fight over whether the billionaire can back out of a $44 billion deal to acquire the company.
articles.lead_paragraph: Twitter has accused Elon Musk, in a lawsuit, of abandoning his planned acquisition of the company because stock market turbulence made the deal more difficult for him. But firing back in a legal filing, Mr. Musk says it was Twitter that torpedoed the $44 billion acquisition.

articles.headline: China Sends Ships and Planes Toward Taiwan, Defying Rising Criticism
articles.snippet: Beijing also halted talks with the United States on the military, climate change and other issues, sending ties between the two powers into a deeper chill.
articles.abstract: Beijing also halted talks with the United States on the military, climate change and other issues, sending ties between the two powers into a deeper chill.
articles.lead_paragraph: China sent a force of warships and aircraft into waters and airspace near Taiwan on Friday, defying international criticism of its military exercises and demonstrating the country’s growing appetite for confrontation over the island that it claims as its territory.
articles.byline: By Jane Perlez, Alexandra Stevenson, John Liu and Michael Crowley

articles.headline: After Losing Favor to Electric Cars, Plug-In Hybrids Gain Ground
articles.snippet: There has been a surge in the sales of cars that can travel short distances on just electricity and have a gasoline engine for longer trips.
articles.abstract: There has been a surge in the sales of cars that can travel short distances on just electricity and have a gasoline engine for longer trips.
articles.lead_paragraph: In late 2010, General Motors sought to seize the high ground from Toyota’s successful Prius hybrid with the Volt plug-in hybrid — a car that could drive short distances on only electricity and fire up a gasoline engine for long trips.

articles.headline: Amtrak Rewarded Executives With Six-Figure Bonuses as Rail Service Struggled
articles.snippet: Most of the top leaders received bonuses above $200,000 in the last fiscal year, as Amtrak worked to recover from the coronavirus pandemic.
articles.abstract: Most of the top leaders received bonuses above $200,000 in the last fiscal year, as Amtrak worked to recover from the coronavirus pandemic.
articles.lead_paragraph: Amtrak’s top executives received six-figure incentive bonuses in 2021, their biggest payouts in years, despite the service’s lackluster financial performance and weak ridership caused by the pandemic, according to data obtained by The New York Times.
articles.byline: By Mark Walker and Niraj Chokshi

articles.headline: With Surge in July, U.S. Recovers the Jobs Lost in the Pandemic
articles.snippet: The increase of 528,000 outstripped expectations, and the gains were spread widely across industries. The jobless rate fell to 3.5 percent.
articles.abstract: The increase of 528,000 outstripped expectations, and the gains were spread widely across industries. The jobless rate fell to 3.5 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: U.S. job growth accelerated in July across nearly all industries, restoring nationwide employment to its prepandemic level, despite widespread expectations of a slowdown as the Federal Reserve raises interest rates to fight inflation.
